I did not find it in the document，I have many jar app in a vm host.  I don't know the loading mechanism of the config file. So I need your guide. Thank you!

@wu-sheng 
I think the config file loading in the same folder at runtime. so I need copy agent folder for each app, is that right?

Could I do like this?
```
java -javaagent:/path/to/agent.jar="agent.service_name=app1" -jar app1.jar
java -javaagent:/path/to/agent.jar="agent.service_name=app2" -jar app2.jar
```
We have very detailed documents. Again, please read document. https://github.com/apache/incubator-skywalking/blob/master/docs/en/setup/service-agent/java-agent/Setting-override.md

# Start up mode
In different deployment tool, such as k8s, you may need different startup mode.
We provide another two optional startup modes.

## Default mode
Default mode. Do initialization works if necessary, start listen and provide service. 

Run `/bin/oapService.sh`(.bat) to start in this mode. Also when use `startup.sh`(.bat) to start.

## Init mode
In this mode, oap server starts up to do initialization works, then exit.
You could use this mode to init your storage, such as ElasticSearch indexes, MySQL and TiDB tables,
and init data.

Run `/bin/oapServiceInit.sh`(.bat) to start in this mode.

## No-init mode
In this mode, oap server starts up without initialization works,
but it waits for ElasticSearch indexes, MySQL and TiDB tables existed,
start listen and provide service. Meaning,
this oap server expect another oap server to do the initialization.

Run `/bin/oapServiceNoInit.sh`(.bat) to start in this mode.
best regards

Roger

We don't support that. If you dive a little deeper for this requirements, you will find actually this is complex. Such as
- Decoding of the HTTP parameter is uncertain, if decode wrong, it will break the application.
- Some stream reader doesn't allow pre-read.
- Performance concern, this is possible only if you are a low throughput system. Tag this parameter will cost a lot of memory, network, and storage.

So, this requirement could be done only in your own env and change the certain plugin.

This idea is fine. but I think this demand is not worth do this currently. Here are the reasons:
1. we need to intercept lots of class to fetch the peers.  
2. it also make a deep change for Agent API 
3. people install agent in producer side and it will install agent in consumer side normally.
OK. Then I am tagging this as `help wanted` and no milestone.

Default lable = instance id

## Metric related
1. Cluster size of each node(gauge).
1. Instance `uptime`(gauge).
1. Mesh/Trace gRPC throughput(counter), latency(histogram)
1. Mesh/Trace buffer file read/write offsite(counter)
1. Aggregation throughput(counter), with labelName = metric name, level = 1 or 2
1. Client side remote, throughput(counter), latency(histogram), with labelName = dest 
1. Server side remote, throughput(counter), latency(histogram)
1. Throughput(counter), latency(histogram) for persistence `buildBatchCollection` and `batch`.
1. JVM metric of each node.
Hostname is based on your OS hostname, agent just collect it.

Thanks for your quick reply!
Could you tell me the details about how to collect the OS hostname, because related the 'hostname' of OS, we may mean different things. the hostname showed in service map page is not the same as the output of hostname command of OS(ubuntu 14.04).
No. That name would not show in service map. Service map is based on service code, not hostname. In real production env, hostname is unique for each vm or container.
when service instance nodes is one vm like aliyun's ecs, what does the 'hostname' mean. we install sw into our services using javaagent method, and our service is run in one tomcat with war package.
OS hostname has just one meanings.  What do you expect? I am confusing. I feel you are creating your own concept.

As a user, we just want to know which service instance nodes the service is now running. but we now can only find string like this on service map page: [Ins:web-pid:32016@localhost Throughput]. [Ins:web-pid:32016@nodexxx Throughput] is what we expect. so we want to know where the [localhost] come from?
It is OS hostname. You could find tons of documents about how to set OS hostname in Google or Baidu.
the question is that we have set a unique hostname for every machine, but on service map page all machine show as  localhost
